title: The Impact of Stress on Physical and Emotional Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Factors Contributing to the Stress Response
content: Insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: Behavioral Changes in Response to Stress
content: Lastly, we discuss how our behavior is altered in the face of stress and how that not only has a pervasive effect on a personal level, but also on society as a whole in how we interact with each other.

content: Individual variation in the response to stress, and how everyone has a different optimal level [24:00]

title: The Impact of Stress on Our Physical and Emotional Health
content: In this episode, Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: The Physiology of Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: The Impact of Stress on Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression. He also talks about the role of stress in cancer and how it can lead to chronic illness.

title: Tips for Managing Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world. He talks about the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: Background and Interest in Stress
content: Robert has been studying the population of wild baboons in East Africa for the last 30 years, trying to answer questions about the relationship between social rank, personality, social affiliation, and stress-related disease. He also spends time studying the effects of cortisol on the brain.

title: Physiology of a Stress Response
content: Stress causes changes in hormones in our body, including adrenaline and glucocorticoids (human version called cortisol). The sympathetic system triggers fight or flight, while the parasympathetic system calms the body. Adrenaline and cortisol work together to respond to stress, with adrenaline triggering the initial response and cortisol providing a slower, longer-lasting response. Cortisol has been serving vertebrates for a long time, helping them respond to life or death situations.

title: Nutrition and Stress Response
content: Glucocorticoids increase glucose levels in your bloodstream and impair digestion. Diseases where people are unable to turn on their endocrine stress response include Addison’s disease and Shy-Drager syndrome. Hormone receptors are more consequential than the level of hormone itself. It is not only “how loudly you speak hormone, but how effectively your cells list to hormone.”

title: Social Rank and Stress Response
content: In baboons, the higher rank in your troop, you have lower levels of glucocorticoid, lower blood pressure, etc. In general, lower status equates to lower health. We also see a similar correlation to rank status and health in humans. We belong to multiple hierarchies at once and we can have very different ranks in them. We are very good psychologically at deciding at whichever hierarchy were highest in and that’s the one we define ourselves by.

title: Personality Differences and Stress Levels
content: Personality differences can impact stress levels. We differ so much as to what each person’s optimum amount of stress is. Some people find bird watching super stimulating, while others need to be a mercenary in Yemen because that’s when they feel alive and awake. It is not only “how loudly you speak hormone, but how effectively your cells list to hormone.”

title: Nutrition not found
content: Sorry, there is no relevant information about nutrition in this text.

title: Epigenetics
content: Early experience, doesn’t change your actual genes/DNA sequence But your early experience can change the regulation of your genes (how easily you turn certain genes on/off in different parts of your body/brain)

title: Stress Effects on Neuronal Structure: Hippocampus, Amygdala, and Prefrontal Cortex
content: The optimal amount of glucocorticoids (something that is moderately “stressful” or stimulating), great stuff to your hippocampus: It increases blood delivery, glucose, and oxygen It makes the synapses (the connections between neurons) more excitable A little bit of arousal/alertness is a good thing for learning and memory Too much stress (i.e. you are stressed 24/7 ever since you were like 10 years old) … now the glucocorticoids are out of the optimal range and they do exactly the opposite to the hippocampus: They decrease oxygen and glucose delivery to the hippocampus They make neurons less excitable They disconnect synapses they cause the processes in neurons to shrivel they block the birth of new neurons If you were stressed out of your mind, memory doesn’t work as well And if you are exposed to excessive glucocorticoid levels for many years, your hippocampus will age more quickly

title: The impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health
content: “When you look at the source of variability in health among humans on this planet, socioeconomic differences, differences in absolute levels, differences in degrees of inequality within cultures and within communities are an enormous predictor of health. You want to look at the most medically impacted low ranking primates you could find on earth? Look at poor humans because when humans invented socio economic status and the capacity to be poor, they invented a way to subordinate the have-nots like no chimp on earth could ever dream of doing.”

title: Nutrition in the Nuba Mountains
content: Tom is an amazing physician practicing in the Nuba Mountains (South Sudan) as the only doctor to a million people. The Nuba people are being bombed and killed by al-Bashir, an evil dictator. Yet Peter would think their cortisol is lower than ours. Probably a combination of a strong sense of community and little subjective status disparity.

title: Explaining the poor health/mental health of westernized countries
content: In the westernized world, there is a health/socioeconomic gradient. Hypothesis #1: If you’re not healthy, it’s very hard to pull off being the CEO of a company. Hypothesis #2: Maybe everybody is equally healthy, but the really poor people are just really unhealthy (i.e. a step function). Hypothesis #3: Lack of healthcare access (neo-materialist explanation). Subjective status and stress. Your socioeconomic status, your wealth, your objective measure of wealth, is indeed a predictor of your health. But it turns out at least as good of a predictor is your subjective socioeconomic status.

title: Technology, social media, and the modern world
content: Social media is the amplifier to all amplifiers of this.

title: The Impact of Social Media on Local Inequality
content: Local inequality is more impactful, yet technology and social media has allowed for an expansion of the definition of “local”. Social media as an amplifier. No matter what century you grew up in, it is possible to experience the corrosive effects of being the last one picked for the game, the least popular kid, etc. But in today’s environment, you can spend 24/7 wallowing toxically in evidence of a gazillion other people who are better looking than you, more popular, etc. Social media and technology makes the vulnerable more damaged than in the past.

title: Managing Stress in the Modern World
content: Of all the things that portend good health (nutrition, exercise, sleep, stress), Peter says he’s most worried about stress (it drives him crazy, he says). Tips for managing stress in the modern world. First off, you must practice regularly with set aside time (i.e. you can’t do your stress management on the weekends, or for the 30 seconds your on hold on the phone). In other words, like exercise you need hours per week of time set aside. Same with nutritional interventions as well as putting a premium on sleep. If you want to combat hypercortisolemia … “It ain’t a 20 minute a week thing.”

title: The Importance of Daily Stress Management
content: Robert says that 10 minutes of deliberate mindful practice of meditation daily would be better than one hour once a week. If you do it daily, you are sitting in the aftermath of having done that versus only one time a week (the recovery period). In the same way, one awful hour long stressor a week versus punctuated episodes of it throughout the week … without question, the latter is worse because you’ve now got umpteen different times that you have to recover from having turned on the stress response and that’s where a lot of the damage occurs (in the recovery period).

title: Email as a Stress Trigger
content: Email is a stress trigger for Peter. He was getting agitated seeing his fluctuations in glucose each time he looked at his email. Resting heart rate would be higher in the morning even after regular exercise that should improve his resting HR. He changed to only looking at email for two 30-minute blocks per day and it really helped.

title: Robert's work as a neuroendocrinologist and primatologist
content: Robert won the MacArthur award in 1987 for his work as a neuroendocrinologist and primatologist.

title: Robert's learning about himself studying the social behavior of baboons
content: As a field biologist, Robert was studying the benefits of social behavior of baboons. He started to realize the irony of the situation. Robert's wife observed this in baboons… Two baboons having the same menstrual cycle. One of them is a totally irritable, awful jerk to all the other females around her for three days afterward.

title: The multilayered factors behind every human behavior, the context of “good and bad”, and exploring the human capacity of the wild extremes of violence and altruism from moment to moment
content: Robert’s book: Behave: The Biology of Humans at Our Best and Worst. The book was about trying to make sense of the biology of a puzzling thing about us as a behaving species, which is we are simultaneously the most miserably violent species on earth and the most altruistic and cooperative and empathic. Any given human is capable of incredible gyrations in wonderful and awful behavior (and everything in between). And whether the behavior counts as good or bad is incredibly dependent on what culture they happen to be doing it in.

title: Multilayered factors of every behavior
content: To make sense of human behavior you got to factor in: What your neurons did one second ago (as well as the environmental triggers that caused that 30 seconds ago), hormone levels were like this morning, neuroplasticity you’ve done over the last two seasons, what your adolescence was like, your childhood, even your fetal life, your genes, what sort of culture were your ancestors inventing centuries ago because that influenced the way you were raised within minutes of birth, what things you value, what things your amygdala does, or does not, respond to, and finally evolution (i.e. why we’re in some ways like chimps and in some ways like bonobos, but we’re not either of those).

title: PMS: How two women with identical hormone levels can have completely different emotional experiences
content: Peter sees PMS purely through the len of the endocrine system (estrogen and progesterone levels fluctuating). What’s fascinating is that 2 women could have the exact same peak and valley in hormones yet report totally different experiences. Peter says it could have something to do with “progesterone receptors”.

title: Genes implicated in depression
content: The single most important gene is the serotonin transporter (targeted with SSRI/Prozac). The gene comes in a few different variants, one of which appears to make you more at risk for major depression. Classic study by Avshalom Caspi. 17,000 people followed from birth to age 25. About 20% of the study population has the “bad” variant of the gene. What they saw is that there was no increase in risk having the bad variant. However, if coupled with a lot of childhood stress, there was about a 20x increase. The same childhood stressors to people without the “bad” gene variant had only a moderate increase in depression incidence. It turns out these different gene variants are regulated in different ways by glucocorticoids (so stress has an impact).

title: Why is cortisol elevated under sleep deprivation?
content: When we are sleep deprived, our cortisol levels are elevated. Peter says, this is counterintuitive. Peter’s possible explanation: if you’re sleep deprived, you’re body is assuming there is a good reason for it so you want cortisol to keep you awake and alert. ⇒ Robert’s take: If you’re a basic mammal and you are wide awake when you’re supposed to be asleep… this does not happen by chance… the odds are you have something stressful going on. The subtle interplay of sleep, sleep quality, and cortisol. What we know now… Circadian peak of glucocorticoids are around the time you wake up. An hour before you wake up, levels begin to rise, not for dealing with a stressor that has already commenced, but in preparation for having to get up and function. Interesting sleep study: Take a group of volunteers. The first night, tell them that this night we’re going to wake you up at 4 AM. The result? ⇒ Around 3 AM their glucocorticoid levels start rising. Then, the next night you tell them I’m going to wake you up at some point during the night and that’s the end of your night’s sleep. Result? ⇒ After 90 minutes (one sleep cycle), their cortisol rises and stays high for the rest of the night. So, not only is it bad not to get enough sleep, and not only is it bad if that insufficient sleep is fragmented, but the worst is if it’s fragmented unpredictably. “And that’s like every medical resident in history.” In med school, Peter will literally tape a pager to his forehead because he was worried about sleeping through the call. “It’s wildly destructive.” It turns out if you have elevated glucocorticoid levels while you’re asleep: You have less delta sleep time (restorative sleep). You make less adenosine stores in your brain.

title: The impact of stress on cancer
content: Stress has a common perception of playing a substantial role in the onset of cancer, but the actual evidence is minimal. Most human studies have too many confounding factors. Animal studies show that under experimental induction of a tumor, stress can accelerate the growth of the tumor. Injecting glucocorticoid to a rat that already has cancer can accelerate tumor growth. Glucocorticoids can be immunosuppressive, but usually, by the time a tumor is growing, it's no longer an immunological problem. Hard to make the case that acute bouts of stress can have any impact on cancer development.

title: What is something that has been shown to increase effectiveness of cancer therapy?
content: Supportive group therapy among cancer patients enhances survival. People in supportive cancer therapy with other people going through the same thing and understand, they become more compliant with their medical regimes.

title: The impact of stress on atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression
content: The damage of hypercortisolemia and the accelerated stress response are probably most demonstrated in cardiovascular disease and atherosclerosis. Cortisol inhibits melatonin secretion, which is a pro-neurogenic molecule, so having less of that is less restorative to the brain. Stress and lots of glucocorticoids can accelerate hippocampal aging (neuron loss, memory problems, and the extent of reactive gliosis).

title: Amygdala
content: Glucocorticoids probably play the driving role in both. Stress and glucocorticoids cause neurons to not work as well, neural networks don’t work as well, and the overall size decreases. In the amygdala, neurons work better than they should, become more excitable, form denser networks, and the amygdala gets bigger in size. In the hippocampus, your memory goes down the tubes. In the amygdala, it leads to anxiety disorders and fear.

title: Dopamine, depression and addiction
content: Stress and glucocorticoids mess with the dopamine system. A messed up dopamine system predisposes us towards the two big psychiatric diseases: addiction and depression. Depression is a disease of inability to feel pleasure and hedonia. Stress will impact judgment, impulse control, executive function, long term planning, strategizing, to name a few. During moments of extreme emotional arousal, your amygdala overpowers your frontal cortex. When we’re very stressed, it’s hard for the frontal cortex to take the view of the world from somebody else’s perspective.

title: Criminal justice system
content: Both Peter and Robert agree that these findings have big implications in the world criminal justice reform. A lot of these things that people have wound up in prison for are really impulsive, horrible decisions, as opposed to decades of sinister planning. And it’s not clear that the environment in there is reducing cortisol levels to the level that would enable rehabilitation.

content: N/A
